introduction.p: It is a remarkable fact that algebra, which is about symbolic equations and their solutions, and geometry are intimately connected. For instance, the solution set of a linear equation in two unknowns, such as 2x + y = 1, can be represented graphically by a straight line. The aim of this section is to further this connection by introducing vectors, which will help us to apply geometric intuition to our thinking about linear systems.

subsection.title: Vectors
subsection.p:
vector A vector is most simply thought of as a matrix with a single column. For instance,
\vvec = \left[ \begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 1 \\ \end{array} \right]
and
\wvec = \left[ \begin{array}{r} -3 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ \end{array} \right]
are both vectors. The entries in a vector are called its components. Since the vector \vvec has two components, we say that it is a two-dimensional vector; in the same way, the vector \wvec is a four-dimensional vector.
We denote the set of all m-dimensional vectors by \real^m. Consequently, if \uvec is a 3-dimensional vector, we say that \uvec is in \real^3.

While it can be difficult to visualize a four-dimensional vector, we can draw a simple picture describing the two-dimensional vector \vvec, as shown in .
A graphical representation of the vector \vvec = \twovec21.
An arrow representing a vector in the plane.
An arrow is drawn to represent the two-dimensional vector \vvec = \twovec21. The diagram contains a 1\times1 coordinate grid and a set of labelled axes. The arrow representing \vvec is drawn so that it begins at the origin (0,0) and extends two unit horizontally and one unit vertically so that its tip is at the point (2,1).

We can think of \vvec as describing a walk in the plane where we move two units horizontally and one unit vertically. Though we allow ourselves to begin walking from any point in the plane, we will most frequently begin at the origin in which case we arrive at the the point (2,1), as shown in the figure.

There are two simple algebraic operations we often perform on vectors.
Scalar Multiplication scalar multiplication
We multiply a vector \vvec by a real number c by multiplying each of the components of \vvec by c. For instance,
-3\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ -4 \\ 1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{r} -6 \\ 12 \\ -3 \\ \end{array}\right].
We will frequently refer to real numbers, such as -3 in this example, as scalars to distinguish them from vectors.
Vector Addition vector addition
We add two vectors of the same dimension by adding their components. For instance,
\left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ -4 \\ 3 \\ \end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{r} -5 \\ 6 \\ -3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{r} -3 \\ 2 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right].

subsection.p: The preview activity demonstrates how we may interpret scalar multiplication and vector addition geometrically.

First, we see that scalar multiplication has the effect of stretching or compressing a vector. Multiplying by a negative scalar changes the direction of the vector. In either case, shows that a scalar multiple of a vector \vvec lies on the same line defined by \vvec.
A vector and several scalar multiples all of which lie on the same line
The vector \vvec=\twovec21 is represented graphically along with scalar multiples 2\vvec, -\vvec and -2\vvec. These vectors lie on the same line, which is also indicated as extending infinitely far in both directions.
Scalar multiples of the vector \vvec=\twovec21.

To represent the sum \vvec + \wvec, we imagine walking from the origin with the appropriate horizontal and vertical changes given by \vvec. From there, we continue our walk using the horizontal and vertical changes prescribed by \wvec, after which we arrive at the sum \vvec + \wvec. This is illustrated on the left of where the tail of \wvec is placed on the tip of \vvec.
Two vectors and their vector sum
A vector \vvec is drawn starting at the origin, and a second vector \wvec is drawn starting from the tip of \vvec. Then the vector sum \vvec+\wvec is drawn from the origin to the tip of \wvec.
Aparallelogram formed by two vectors with their sum drawn as a diagonal.
Two vectors \vvec and \wvec are shown forming a parallelogram.
One half of the parallelogram is formed by placing an arrow that starts at the origin and represents \vvec. From the tip of \vvec, a second arrow is shown representing \wvec.
The second half of the parallelogram is formed by placing an arrow that starts at the origin and represents \wvec. From the tip of this vector, another arrow is shown representing \vvec.
One set of opposite sides of the parallelogram are representations of \vvec while the other set of opposite sides are representations of \wvec.
The vector sum \vvec+\wvec is shown as an arrow that begins at the origin and has its tip at the opposite corner of the parallelogram.
Vector addition as a simple walk in the plane is illustrated on the left. The vector sum is represented as the diagonal of a parallelogram on the right.
Alternatively, we may construct the parallelogram with \vvec and \wvec as two sides. The sum is then the diagonal of the parallelogram, as illustrated on the right of .

We have now seen that the set of vectors having the form c\vvec is a line. To form the set of vectors c\vvec+\wvec, we can begin with the vector \wvec and add multiples of \vvec. Geometrically, this means that we begin from the tip of \wvec and move in a direction parallel to \vvec. The effect is to translate the line c\vvec by the vector \wvec, as shown in .
Representations of vectors obtained by multiplying one vector by scalars and adding to another vector.
Two vectors \vvec and \wvec are shown, both of which begin at the origin. The line defined by \vvec is also shown as extending infinitely far in both direction, while a second infinite line parallel to \vvec is drawn passing through the tip of \wvec. The vectors obtained as c\vvec+\wvec for scalars c=-2,-1,0,1,2 are shown starting at the origin with their tips on the second line parallel to \vvec.
The set of vectors c\vvec + \wvec form a line.

At times, it will be useful for us to think of vectors and points interchangeably. That is, we may wish to think of the vector \left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] as describing the point (2,1) and vice-versa. When we say that the vectors having the form c\vvec + \wvec form a line, we really mean that the tips of the vectors all lie on the line passing through \wvec and parallel to \vvec.

observation.p:
Even though these vector operations are new, it is straightforward to check that some familiar properties hold.
Commutativity
\vvec + \wvec = \wvec + \vvec.
Distributivity
a(\vvec + \wvec) = a\vvec + a\wvec.

subsection.title: Linear combinations
subsection.p: Linear combinations, which we encountered in the preview activity, provide the link between vectors and linear systems. In particular, they will help us apply geometric intuition to problems involving linear systems.

subsection.p: This activity illustrates how linear combinations are constructed geometrically: the linear combination c\vvec + d\wvec is found by walking along \vvec a total of c times followed by walking along \wvec a total of d times. When one of the weights is held constant while the other varies, the vector moves along a line.

statement.p:
The previous activity also shows that questions about linear combinations lead naturally to linear systems. Suppose we have vectors \vvec = \twovec3{-1} and \wvec=\twovec43. Let's determine whether we can describe the vector \bvec=\twovec{-11}{-18} as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec. In other words, we would like to know whether there are weights c and d such that
c\vvec + d\wvec= \bvec.

To solve this linear system, we construct its corresponding augmented matrix and find its reduced row echelon form,
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 3 \amp 4 \amp -11 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp -18 \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -5 \end{array} \right],
giving us the weights c=3 and d=-5; that is,
3\vvec -5 \wvec = \bvec . In fact, we know more because the reduced row echelon matrix tells us that these are the only possible weights. Therefore, \bvec may be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec in exactly one way.

subsection.p: This example demonstrates the connection between linear combinations and linear systems. Asking whether a vector \bvec is a linear combination of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is equivalent to asking whether an associated linear system is consistent.

In fact, we may easily describe the associated linear system in terms of the vectors \vvec, \wvec, and \bvec. Notice that the augmented matrix we found in our example was
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 3 \amp 4 \amp -11 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp -18 \end{array} \right].
The first two columns of this matrix are \vvec and \wvec and the rightmost column is \bvec. As shorthand, we will write this augmented matrix replacing the columns with their vector representation:
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} \vvec \amp \wvec \amp \bvec \end{array} \right] . This fact is generally true so we record it in the following proposition.

statement.p:
The vector \bvec is a linear combination of the vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n if and only if the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[ \begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array} \right]
is consistent. A solution to this linear system gives weights c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_n such that
c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + c_n\vvec_n = \bvec .

statement.p: Consider the vectors \vvec=\twovec{-1}1 and \wvec=\twovec{2}{-2}, as shown in .

image.shortdescription: Two vectors that lie on the same line.

description.p: Two vectors, \vvec=\twovec{-1}1 and \wvec=\twovec2{-2} are represented by arrows starting at the origin. These arrows lie on the same line, and that line is also shown extending infinitely far in both directions.

statement.p:
These vectors appear to lie on the same line, a fact that becomes apparent once we notice that \wvec = -2\vvec. Intuitively, we think of the linear combination
c\vvec + d\wvec
as the result of walking c times in the \vvec direction and d times in the \wvec direction. With these vectors, we are always walking along the same line so it would seem that any linear combination of these vectors should lie on the same line. In addition, a vector that is not on the line, say \bvec = \twovec30, should be not be expressible as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec.

We can verify this by checking
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} -1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right].
This shows that the associated linear system is inconsistent, which means that the vector \bvec=\twovec30 cannot be written as a linear combination of \vvec and \wvec.

Notice that the reduced row echelon form of the coefficient matrix
\begin{bmatrix} \vvec \amp \wvec \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}
tells us to expect this. Since there is not a pivot position in the second row of the coefficient matrix \begin{bmatrix}\vvec \amp \wvec \end{bmatrix}, it is possible for a pivot position to appear in the rightmost column of the augmented matrix
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|r} \vvec \amp \wvec \amp \bvec \end{array} \right]
for some choice of \bvec.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
This section has introduced vectors, linear combinations, and their connection to linear systems.
There are two operations we can perform with vectors: scalar multiplication and vector addition. Both of these operations have geometric meaning.
Given a set of vectors and a set of scalars we call weights, we can create a linear combination using scalar multiplication and vector addition.
A solution to the linear system whose augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
is a set of weights that expresses \bvec as a linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n.
